working with cli tools learn more cinder volume service nova compute a component within the openstack open source cloud computing platform developed to provide on-demand access to compute resources by provisioning and managing large networks of virtual machines (vms). glance image service the openstack image service that provides discovery, registration and delivery services for disk and server images. it has the ability to copy (or snapshot) a server image and then to store it promptly. neutron networking an openstack networking project focused on delivering networking-as-a-service (naas) in virtual compute environments. the openstack block storage service designed to present storage resources to end users that can be consumed by the openstack nova compute project. cinder cinder cinder glance glance glance neutron neutron neutron nova nova nova what is nova? nova is the openstack project that provides a way to provision compute instances (aka virtual servers). nova supports creating virtual machines, bare-metal servers (through the use of ironic), and has limited support for system containers. nova runs as a set of daemons on top of existing linux servers to provide that service. it requires the following additional openstack services for basic function: keystone: provides identity and authentication for all openstack services. glance: provides the compute image repository. all compute instances launch from glance images. neutron: responsible for provisioning the virtual or physical networks that compute instances connect to on boot. it can also integrate with other services to include: persistent block storage, encrypted disks, and bare-metal compute instances. tools for using nova horizon: the official web ui for the openstack project. openstack client: the official cli for openstack projects. you should use this as your cli for most things, it includes not just nova commands but also commands for most of the projects in openstack. nova client: for some very advanced features (or administrative commands) of nova you may need to use nova client. it is still supported, but the openstack cli is recommended. nova compute https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/ what is neutron? openstack networking (neutron) allows you to create and attach interface devices managed by other openstack services to networks. plug-ins can be implemented to accommodate different networking equipment and software, providing flexibility to openstack architecture and deployment. neutron-server accepts and routes api requests to the appropriate openstack networking plug-in for action. openstack networking plug-ins and agents plug and unplug ports, create networks or subnets, and provide ip addressing. these plug-ins and agents differ depending on the vendor and technologies used in the particular cloud. openstack networking ships with plug-ins and agents for cisco virtual and physical switches, nec openflow products, open vswitch, linux bridging, and the vmware nsx product. the common agents are l3 (layer 3), dhcp (dynamic host ip addressing), and a plug-in agent. messaging queue used by most openstack networking installations to route information between the neutron-server and various agents. also acts as a database to store networking state for particular plug-ins. openstack networking mainly interacts with openstack compute to provide networks and connectivity for its instances. neutron networking https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/ glance image service what is glance? the image service (glance) project provides a service where users can upload and discover data assets that are meant to be used with other services. this currently includes images and metadata definitions. glance image services include discovering, registering, and retrieving virtual machine (vm) images. glance has a restful api that allows querying of vm image metadata as well as retrieval of the actual image. vm images made available through glance can be stored in a variety of locations from simple filesystems to object-storage systems like the openstack swift project. https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/ cinder volume service https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/ what is cinder? cinder block storage adds persistent storage to a virtual machine. block storage provides an infrastructure for managing volumes, and interacts with openstack compute to provide volumes for instances. the service also enables management of volume snapshots, and volume types. the block storage service consists of the following components: cinder-api: accepts api requests, and routes them to the cinder-volume for action. cinder-volume: interacts directly with the block storage service, and processes such as the cinder-scheduler. it also interacts with these processes through a message queue. the cinder-volume service responds to read and write requests sent to the block storage service to maintain state. it can interact with a variety of storage providers through a driver architecture. cinder-scheduler daemon: selects the optimal storage provider node on which to create the volume. a similar component to the nova-scheduler. cinder-backup daemon: the cinder-backup service provides backing up volumes of any type to a backup storage provider. like the cinder-volume service, it can interact with a variety of storage providers through a driver architecture. messaging queue: routes information between the block storage processes.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to VMware® Integrated OpenStack Fundamentals.
Take a moment to review the module objectives.

What is VMware Integrated OpenStack? Before answering that question, let us take a look at OpenStack.

OpenStack is an open-source framework for delivering cloud-based IaaS.

OpenStack provides applications with API-access to cloud services. It is best suited for cloud-native applications that are specifically designed for cloud computing environments as opposed to applications that are simply being migrated to the cloud.

OpenStack provides infrastructure delivery with different services. Each of these services is known by its OpenStack project name.:

OpenStack compute, or Nova, is a cloud fabric controller, which is the main part of an IaaS system. It is designed to manage and automate pools of computer resources and can work with widely available virtualization technologies, as well as bare metal and high-performance computing (HPC) configurations.

OpenStack networking is provided by Neutron, a system for managing networks and OP addresses. Neutron ensures the network is not a bottleneck or limiting factor in a cloud deployment, and gives users self-service over network configurations.

Neutron provides networking models for different applications or user groups. Standard modelsmodesl include flat networks or VLANs that separate servers and traffic. Neutron manages IP addresses, allowing for dedicated static IP addresses or DHCP. Floating IP addresses allow dynamic traffic re-routing to any resources in the IT infrastructure, so users can redirect traffic during maintenance or in case of a failure.

Cinder is a block storage service. It virtualizes pools of block storage devices and provides end users with a self-service API to request and consume those resources without requiring any knowledge of where their storage is actually deployed or on what type of device.

Glance is anthe OpenStack image service providing discovery, registration, and delivery services for disk and server images. Stored images can becanbe used as a template for instances, which are individual VMs. It can also be used to store and catalog an unlimited number of backups. The image serviceImage Service can store disk and server images in a variety of back ends, including OpenStack Object Storage. The Glance API provides a standard REST interface for querying information about disk images and lets clients stream the images to new servers.

Keystone provides identity services in a central directory of users mapped to the OpenStack services they can access. It acts as a common authentication system across the cloud operating system and can integrate with existing backend directory services such aslike LDAP. It supports multiple forms of authentication including standard user nameusername and password credentials, token-based systems, and logins. The catalog also provides a list of all the services deployed in an OpenStackopenstack cloud in a single registry.

Developers can automate access or build tools to manage resources using the native OpenStacknatibve OPenStack API or the EC2 compatibility API.

Heat provides OpenStack orchestration, allowing you to automate many aspects of managing your IaaS infrastructure. It provides an alternative to vRealize Orchestrator for organizations that have an existing library of Heat-based orchestrations.

Ceilometer project is a data collection service that provides the ability to normalizenormalise and transform data across OpenStack core components. Its data can be used to provide customer billing, resource tracking, and alarm capabilities.

Before we get started with building our IaaS infrastructure, let us review some terminology that is commonly associated with OpenStack.

An Image refers to virtual machine templates stored and indexed through Glance. The virtual machine template is a file representation of an instance containing an operating system and associated file system structure. An image does not contain any application data, which is stored elsewhere, usually on SAN. Typically, an image is created outside the OpenStack framework and is deployed on virtual machines of different flavors. The flavor of a virtual machine defines the number of vCPUs, memory allocated, and disk size assigned to the image when it is created.

An Instance is a running virtual machine image and the associated volumes hosted on a hypervisor. Image files are copied whenever a new instance is created.

A Flavor specifies the resources available to an instance as defined in it's image. The flavor defines instance characteristics such as the number of processors, amount of memory, disk space, operating system, networking, and other components of a functioning virtual machine.

A Tenant, often called a Project, is created by the OpenStack administrator and assigned to a user or user group who can then create virtual machine instances. The definition of each project also includes a definition for networking connectivity for the instances that are created. The network definition can also include the tenant network, external networks, and associated blocks of IP addresses and subnets.

A User represents a human user. The information associated with the user includes the user name, password, and email.

A Role captures the operations that a user can perform on a given tenant.

Begin by creating a new user.

In the Identity Panel, select Users. This shows all the users created in the OpenStack deployment including the users for individual services such as Nova, Glance, Cinder, and Neutron, as well as the admin user and a demo user.

Next, specify resource quotas to determine the quantity of VCPU, RAM, storage, networks, floating IPs, and other components that a project is allowed to have. Once specified, you can create the new project.

Once the project creation is complete, you can create a new user to complete the process. You can create a user with or without the user creation wizard.

An Image is used to spin off instances that have the configuration defined in the image.

An Image is an OpenStack terminology for a VM template.

Select the Images menu in the Horizon menu on the left navigation, then select the Create Image button to start the image creation wizard.

On the Create an Image page, enter relevant details about the image including name, the source, and virtual machine format details, such as disk format, disk type, storage adapter type, operating system, and other parameters. Now let us look at how how to deploy an instance using the OpenStack Horizon interface.

In Horizon, select the Instances menu on the left navigation pane. Select Launch Instance to bring up the Instance Creation wizard.

On the Details tab, provide basic information about the instance, such as the instance name, flavor, number of instances, and boot source.

The Access and Security tab lets you access the instance with key pairs, security groups, and other mechanisms such as TCP and UDP ports after an instance is launched.

The "who can access" is determined by the Key Pair value, which represents either an SSH key entry to the instance's authorized hosts file, or a Privacy Enhanced Mail, or PEM file.

The Security Groups setting governs which IPs can access your instance over which TCP and UDP ports. Choose a Key Pair name that you can recognize later and paste your SSH public key under the Public Key space in the Import Key Pair panel.

Under the Networking tab, select the network you want the instance to use for communication.

After completing this process, launch the instance. You can then begin deploying applications on it.

You can also use the Nova CLI to complete this process.

You can create storage volumes directly in the VMware Integrated OpenStack Horizon dashboard.

You can also attach a volume to an instance to provide persistent storage.

Storage volumes can be created as sourceless, empty volumes or sourced from snapshots and images.

Volumes are block devices that can be attached to instances. In Horizon, start by selecting the Volumes menu on the left navigation pane, and then select Create Volume to start the volume creation wizard.

On the Create Volume page, provide basic information about the volume such as name, size, and so on. Then select Create Volume.

Attach the volume to an instance. Select the Attachments tab and choose Edit Attachments from the drop-down menu.

On the Manage Volume Attachments page, choose an instance from the list and attach the volume to it.

Create a valid partition, format it, and mount it to a directory. It is then ready for use.

You can also use the CLI, using the Cinder create command and the Nova volume-attach commands.

Begin by examining the existing networks from the Horizon UI.

Create the provider network that all tenants use for external communication. Only a user with administrator privileges can create this network.

What is Kubernetes?

Before we get into what Kubernetes is, let us examine why you would want to use it.

Tools like Docker make it easy to create and deploy containers. Most developers or cloud administrators can easily manage applications deployed to a few servers.

But what if you need to scale quickly to perhaps dozens or hundreds of servers? How are you going to manage that?

This is where Kubernetes comes in.

Kubernetes is a platform for working with containers.

At its core, Kubernetes gives you an easy method of deploying container applications, scaling your infrastructure up or down, and monitoring applications and servers.

Let us take a closer look at how Kubernetes accomplishes all this.

There are a number of architectural components to Kubernetes but here we will discuss two. The first is the Kubernetes master node which provides cluster services.

The fundamental premise behind Kubernetes is that we can enforece Desired State Management. That means we can feed the cluster services a specific configuration and it will be up to the cluster services to deploy, scale, and monitor that configuration in the infrastructure.

The Kubernetes API is the front-end of the Kubernetes cluster services control pane. The API exposes all of the cluster services for your infrastructure.

The second building block is the worker. A worker is a container host. Your infrastructure can have one or many workers.

Each worker has a Kublet process that is responsible for communicating with the Kubernetes Cluster Services.

So the cluster services and the workers make up the Kubernetes cluster.

In this example, we want feed the the cluster services the configuration,

What is Kubernetes on VMware Integrated OpenStack?

Kubernetes is a leading open-source system for automating the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

Application containerization is a virtualization method for deploying and running distributed applications without launching an entire virtual machine. Instead, multiple self-contained application containers can reside on a control host, which can handle one or many containers.

Containerization increases agility and time-to-value, allowing developers to deploy and update applications on an on-going basis. Kubernetes is the leading system for automating container deployment and is now available as part of VMware Integrated OpenStack.

So why are we offering Kubernetes on VMware Integrated OpenStack?

The reason is simple. VMware has dramatically simplified Kubernetes. Installation is as simple as deploying a virtual appliance. And we provide full lifecycle management to the container space which has traditionally been very complex.

Let us examine what Kubernetes on VMware Integrated OpenStack delivers to developers and end users.

VMware Integrated OpenStack, which consists of OpenStack running on VMware SDDC infrastructure, provides the foundation for delivering containerized applications.

OpenStack uses the open source Terraform with Ansible automation to create and manage the Kubernetes master and worker nodes.

Developers and cloud administrators interact with the API server on the master node, which provides the cluster’s control plane for configuring and deploying container applications to the worker Kubernetes nodes.

End uses access deployed container applications, or Pods, on the Kubernetes worker nodes which provide all of the services needed to run the application pods.

Once the master and worker virtual machines are created, Kargo assigns personality to the nodes. Kargo is a Kubernetes incubator project. Personality is simply the components and configuration needed for the node to serve as either a master or worker.

On the master node, etcd is a distributed key value store that provides a reliable way of storing API objects across a cluster of Kubernets node. It supports the Kubernetes API Server which is the access point when a client launches an application or does any other action in the environment. The Scheduler places workloads onto the workers. The scheduler is fully aware of the topology and supports policies to enforce the type of placement. The controller manager maintains the state on the master nodes.

On the worker node, kube-proxy is responsible for programming service forwarding policies so client requests can reach the containers in the backend. The kubelet is responsible for running pods. Kubelet works in terms of a PodSpec. A Podspec is a YAML or JSON object that describes a pod. The kublet takes a set of PodSpecs and ensures that containers described in those PodSpecs are running and healthy.

Deploying Kubernetes on VMware Integrated OpenStack is very simple, allowing you to provide full lifecycle management for containers, a task that traditionally has been very complex.

Using the vCenter user interface, you simply deploy and configure the Kubernetes OVA file, create a Kubernetes provider, and create a cluster. You can provide container services to a developer in minutes rather than the lengthy and complex procedures normally with Kubernetes deploy. VMware has abstracted all of the complexity from cloud administration so admins can deliver the services that container developers want, starting a journey of collaboration with a community of developers to provide the services and tooling that they are looking for.

The APIs we offer for Kubernetes are 100 percent standards-based.

Deploy the Kubernetes virtual appliance on vCenter, using the standard deployment process that VMware administrators are familiar with. Simply download the OVA file, then in vCenter you install and configure the virtual appliance.

Specify a name, a cluster where you want to deploy the OVA file, the datastore where you want the OVA to be copied to, and set up the networking including the IP address and which core group you want the OVA to attach to. We are deploying on the Management Network.

Once the virtual appliance has been deployed, you can create the Kubernetes provider and cluster.

The Kubernetes Provider interacts with Kubernetes resources. The provider must be configured with the proper credentials before it can be used. The provider is the container “glue” to OpenStack.

1. Create the provider. Once the Kubernetes OVF is deployed, copy its IP address and use a browser to access the web interface to configure the provider.

2. Enter the OpenStack Keystone credentials and project where clusters should be created.

3. Select the image that you want to use to create your cluster.

4. Specify the Flavor, or size, of the virtual machine.

5. Configure networking. For VMware Integrated OpenStack, there are three networking backends that the customer can deploy - NSXv, vDS and NSX Transformer. Network backend setting maps to three kinds of container network plugins: flannel, canal and NCP. The flannel container network plugin is the default option for Kubernetes on VMware Integrated OpenStack. If you don’t make a selection for Network, flannel will be used. If the network infrastructure is backed by NSX-T, the NCP container network plugin will be used.

6. Enter the security group. Security group should allow at all traffic required by the Kubernetes control plane on ports 443, 11000, and 11001, as well as application ports required to access the container.

7. Select External and Tenant Networking.

All of the components that you see in the Add new infrastructure provicer wizard need to be in place prior to starting the wizard.

A container engine cluster is a group of Compute Engine instances running Kubernettes. It consists of one or more node instances and a managed Kubernetes master endpoint. A container cluster s the foundation of a Container Engine application.

1. Once the provider is available, you can create a Kubernetes cluster. The UI shows Create Providers and Create Clusters. You select the provider because the provider has everything needed to create the virtual machines including which network to use and what image to use. Everything we did in the previous step of creating the provider is really just attributes of the virtual machines we are going to create for the cluster.

2. Specify the number of VMs for the master node and worker nodes. The number of worker nodes depends on the workloads they will be handling. A minimum of one master node and worker node is required. A single master node or worker node implies no redundancy. For High Availability, it’s a good idea to have at least two worker and master nodes. You can scale the number of worker nodes once the cluster is created. A cluster can be crated in Shared mode or Exclusive mode. Use shared mode if a single Kubernetes cluster will be shared with many users or groups of users using the concept of namespaces in Kubernetes. Namespaces are the way to partition a single Kubernetes cluster into multiple virtual clusters. VMware Integrated OpenStack with Kubernetes builds on these concepts to offer easy namespace management and enforcement of ACL policies. Clusters can be created in an Exclusive Mode where the users or groups of users of the cluster are not isolated from one another.

3. Once the cluster is deployed, you can verify the deployment in the Instances dashboard in Horizon to examine the the master and worker nodes. Only the master node has a public IP address assigned, with the worker nodes on the private subnet.

4. Next, add a namespace. Once a cluster is created, multiple development teams will have access the cluster. The namespace lets you keep the developers separated by assigning users to the namespace. The users are all present in Keystone, so they already exist in. ou assign a name to the namespace and add the users that will have access to that namespace.

Note that all users are authenticated through the Keystone user repository for the OpenStack authentication.

All of the steps so far have been completed by the cloud administrator. Now we will focus on the developer, who creates and deploys container applications to Kubernetes.

1. The cloud administrator provides the API endpoint and cluster name to the developer. Developers will use their authentication credentials that are stored in Keystone.

2. The developer takes that information, typically saving it to a configuration stored locally. It’s not a requirement to save that information to a config file but doing so avoids being prompted every time you access the cluster. The developer adds the API endpoint, the cluster name, and the namespace of the application that you want to use, which is information that is readily available from the cloud administrator.

3. With the config file in place, you can issue commands to retrieve information about available resources in the cluster. A “Pod” is Kubernetes abstraction for containers. A pod is comprised of one or many containers. A service is how you expose a pod to external or internal resources. The service provides access to the pod.

4. A Kubernetes workload is made of pods, replicasets and services. YAML <pronounced YAMl as one word, accent on YAM> is used to describe attributes of the Kubernetes workload. Kubectl is the command line interface for running commands against Kubernetes clusters. Use the kubectl pointing to the YAML file to launch the ecommerce application. The Kubectl will use information defined in the YAML file to deploy resources required for the ecommerce application such as a database, catalog, payment system, and all the other components that the application requires.

5. Once this is deployed you would then use kubectl check to see if the deployed components are running or not, what state they are in, and which node they belong to. You can also get the services that relate to that pod. In this example, the pod contains many containers. What is important here is that the frontend is the external access IP address for users and it is based on a load balancer.

6. Once the application is deployed, end users can access it in a web browser.

OpenStack is an open-source framework for delivering cloud-based Infrastructure as a Service, or IaaS. As a cloud operating system, OpenStack controls large pools of compute, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter. It provides cloud-style APIs that simplify the consumption of virtual infrastructure technologies.

OpenStack itself does not provide the virtual infrastructure. It needs the underlying hypervisor, networking, and storage which are provided by different vendors. OPenStack also does not include the majority of cloud management functionality, such as monitoring, troubleshooting, policies, and governance.

OpenStack provides applications with an API-driven access to cloud services. It is best suited to cloud-native applications that are specifically designed for cloud computing environments as opposed to applications that are simply being migrated to the cloud.
